awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Workshops to Develop a Community-Informed Framework Characterizing the Impact of Engineering Education R&D
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to broadly and comprehensively define impact in the context of engineering education research, allowing the results of that research to be used more effectively in the education of future engineers. By doing so this project will increase the impact of NSF's prior and future investments in engineering education research. Researchers and educators will work together to develop a shared understanding and language around how engineering education research can influence educational practice. This will enable them to effectively articulate the impact of their work to diverse audiences and more carefully plan broad impacts for their future work. The results will provide a basis for future studies on better indicators and measures for assessing impact at the project level and across funding programs as well as directly impact current engineering programs.

This project is engaging the global engineering education community in creating a valid research impact framework for the field of engineering education that is inclusive of researchers and practitioners' perspectives on impact; and describing practitioners' insights on the role of research in engineering education practice. In an environment of increased accountability, engineering education researchers are being asked to identify the tangible impacts of their work on a regular basis. Unfortunately, there is a dearth of scholarship within and beyond engineering education on how to characterize the impact of research. A shared understanding among engineering education researchers and practitioners of what research impact looks like for this field lends itself to conversations on how engineering education research can influence practice. The engineering education research impact framework resulting from this study will draw broadly upon the perspectives of practitioners and researchers as well as existing research impact frameworks developed by other disciplines, including health sciences and science in general. As such, it will be robustly relevant across a wide range of engineering education research and practice activities. Workshops, interviews and recruitment procedures ensure representation of perspectives from a wide range of stakeholders and experts. The methodological approach to achieving the project goal adapts an instrument development procedure for framework development and validation, and will serve as the basis for a follow up study of an impact assessment. Because this project seeks to broadly and comprehensively define impact in the context of engineering education research, the resulting definition will extend beyond esoteric scientific impacts such as journals and academic communities to focus on the social impacts of engineering education and related research. Workshops engage a large number of community members in development, which positively impacts awareness, quality, robustness of usability/applicability, dissemination, buy in, and helps develop consensus in the community around impact. Additional efforts and interviews will ensure representation of practitioner perspectives in the resulting framework, even if these groups do not attend the engineering education conferences. This work may also inform initiatives around broader impacts in other engineering disciplines and across NSF.

por.por_cntn:
Impact is a familiar topic of discussion among engineering education stakeholders, but is an area of study that does not have a robust body of scholarship associated with it. This project has helped to start a more sophisticated discussion about the impact of engineering education research and innovations among various stakeholders in the EER community. Through data collection and dissemination, the findings of this work were informed by and/or shared with researchers, practitioners, administrators, policy makers in the domestic and international EER community. Additionally, the framework resulting from this study will also be useful for facilitating a shared language among members of the EER community about ways to characterize impact in this context. Moreover, the analysis of the interview data revealed detailed nuances about a familiar dilemma-- namely the reasons why there is such a large chasm between research and practice-- and some promising options for addressing this issue. 

    The most significant results of this study relate to: a) the development of constructs and examples in an impact framework for the field of engineering education, and b) understanding reasons why research and its impact are so disconnected in engineering education. The impact of research has three primary dimensions: scientific, contextual, and societal impact. Scientific impact is largely consistent across disciplines (e.g., publications, citations). An example of a scientific impact descriptor in the engineering education research impact framework is: Increase in the stock of scholarly resources that advance knowledge and understanding. The major contribution of this study is more clarity and consensus around the contextual and societal impacts of EER. There is growing agreement around what some forms of contextual impact look like for engineering education research. Examples include: Development of assessments that measure department-level metrics (e.g., retention, program level outcomes);  Changes in attitudes towards STEM-related topics or capabilities; and Fitness and/or extent to which the training prepares the learner for a successful career. There is also a growing sense of agreement around the societal impact of engineering education research. Examples include: Influence on the discourses and actions of groups; and Improved public understanding and support of an issue, research. 

   This project included conducting interviews with engineering education researchers, practitioners, administrators, student advisors, and staff in teaching and learning centers to understand the underlying reasons for the disconnect between research and practice.  Three categories of reasons for the disconnect between research and practice in engineering education resulted from analyzing this data. These barriers relate to the research content, the capabilities of researchers and practitioners, and the contexts in which research and practice occur. Examples of content barriers include jargon-laden publications, challenges associated with locating or accessing research content, and the lack of research on topics relevant to practitioners. Furthermore, capacity-related barriers related to necessary knowledge and skills that researchers and practitioners lack in order to bridge connections. This includes, but is not limited to, communication issues. Lastly, context-related barriers relate to things like the silos in which researchers and practitioners operate, punitive reward structures that de-motivate researchers and/or practitioners from engaging in impact activities, and the role of leadership in facilitating impact.  

   Various people were involved in the research processes associated with this project. The graduate students involved in this study learned a variety of skills related to performing quantitative cluster analysis, conducting qualitative interview research, analyzing interviews using thematic analysis, and publishing results in various formats. Students from other fields (i.e., industrial engineering, software engineering, education policy, education psychology) also learned about engineering education research through their involvement in this interdisciplinary project. Moreover, this project had a long-term goal of improving engineering education by bridging the disconnect between research and practice, and promoting a more comprehensive understanding of how research should influence what various stakeholders in engineering education do. This was accomplished through engaging a unique combination of engineering education stakeholders in the data collection process and by disseminating findings via traditional and nontraditional publication formats (e.g., conference presentations, journal manuscripts, webinars, infographics, keynote addresses).
